The study has been a nearly annual effort going back to 2007, each year studying the demographics of the 100 most popular films at the North American box office. snippet: TRAUB--Margaret A. (Peggy), beloved spouse, daughter, sister, aunt, friend and mentor to many, passed away January 13, 2014 peacefully at her home at the age of 55. Peggy is survived by her loving spouse Phyllis Dicker, her mother Lee Traub (Marvi...
lead_paragraph: TRAUB--Margaret A. (Peggy), beloved spouse, daughter, sister, aunt, friend and mentor to many, passed away January 13, 2014 peacefully at her home at the age of 55. Peggy is survived by her loving spouse Phyllis Dicker, her mother Lee Traub (Marvin, deceased), her brothers Andrew (Lois) and James (Buffy), her brother-in-law Larry Dicker (Shelly), and her nieces and nephews. Peggy was an industry leader in lighting and home decor as a co-founder and president of Adesso. She was a believer in the powers of networking and mentoring, particularly in support of professional and business women. In 1997 she co-founded Withlt, Women in the Home Industries Today. Peggy was a dedicated member of the Women Presidents' Organization, the Women's Leadership Board at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, and the Committee of 200. A 1980 graduate and devoted alumna of Harvard College, Peggy and her spouse cosponsored a scholarship for female college students. Peggy was a supporter of GLAAD and passionate about empowering the LGBT community. Peggy was an active member of Congregation Beit Simchat Torah. Peggy was respected, admired and loved by all whose lives were enriched by her presence. Services Tuesday January 14 at 2:00pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Congregation Beit Simchat Torah or the LGBT Community Center of New York. May her name be for a blessing.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUB, MARGARET A

lead_paragraph: With a loud hiccup and a hand over her mouth in coy embarrassment, Madame Tayoush mimics Lebanese diva Sabah in her performance of the sultry classic "Atshana" — or "I'm Thirsty" — as Arab-Americans hoot and cheer. The burst of a trumpet vibrato sends her into a dramatic swoon, basking under applause and the warmth of stage lights.

headline.main: Gay Arab-Americans Find Room of Their Own in NYC
headline.print_headline: Gay Arab-Americans Find Room of Their Own in NYC

snippet: In a story Feb. 22 about a study on the diversity of the entertainment industry by the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism, The Associated Press misstated two statistics. The study found that 3.4 p...
lead_paragraph: In a story Feb. 22 about a study on the diversity of the entertainment industry by the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism, The Associated Press misstated two statistics. The study found that 3.4 percent of directors were female among the directors examined, not, as was reported, in the films examined. And Netflix scored 25 percent, not 20 percent, on the study's "inclusivity index."

headline.main: Correction: Entertainment Equality Study Story
headline.print_headline: Correction: Entertainment Equality Study Story

headline.main: Answers About Transgender Issues

snippet: North Carolina legislators decided to rein in local governments by approving a bill Wednesday that prevents cities and counties from passing their own anti-discrimination rules. Gov. Pat McCrory later signed the legislation, which dealt a blow to ...
lead_paragraph: North Carolina legislators decided to rein in local governments by approving a bill Wednesday that prevents cities and counties from passing their own anti-discrimination rules. Gov. Pat McCrory later signed the legislation, which dealt a blow to the LGBT movement after success with protections in cities across the country.

headline.print_headline: North Carolina Reins in Local Governments, Transgender Rule
